neutron/agent/l3/agent.py.message:
@Liu This is the line that becomes a problem. At L781 self.sync_routers_chunk_size becomes a float. The range function is unable to deal with floats.

EX:

>>> range(0, 10, float(2))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: range() integer step argument expected, got float.
This should always be exponential times to interger 2, so can you verify why here we get a odd number?
I think a follow-up patch is probably in order to track down other cases like this if they exist.

LIU, it is always even number but it's how python3 works, look:

in py 2.7:

    >>> type(4/2)
    <type 'int'>

but in py 3.6:

    >>> type(4/2)
    <class 'float'>

So '//' integer division can work in both version, how about that?

And can we search and fix such thing once for all?
Maybe this is the root cause of this issue. But I still not sure how we can get a odd value which is larger than SYNC_ROUTERS_MIN_CHUNK_SIZE(32)
I wonder how this wasn't visible in any, even unit test. Maybe it's worth to add some test to cover this part of code?

gbpservice/neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml.message: It seems a bit odd to test this in _test_router_interface(), as I don't think it has anything to do with routing. I guess its better to add it here than create a whole new test, but I'm wondering if it would make sense to instead add a test_port_lifecycle_svi_network() method below that calls _do_test_port_lifecycle(svi_net=True). If the rest of that test is (mostly) applicable to SVI networks, I think it would make sense, but if not, leaving it here is OK.

The change in this patch is not SVI specific though. And as you can see around line#1633, it also tests some subnet update that's why I think it should be ok to test another subnet update in this function.

Kent, I wasn't suggesting SVI should apply to external networks, and agree a separate patch to address that combination makes sense. My suggestion was simply that if calling _do_test_port_lifecycle() made sense for SVI networks (in addition to the other network types its already called for, then all the testing of the host_routes update notifications could be done from that function. I've looked a bit closer at that function, and see that not really a better place to be testing host_routes updates. Ideally, we'd have one test method that tests all kinds of updates and resulting notifications, for all types of networks, but this doesn't seem to currently exist, so your approach is OK for now.

I didn't mean to imply the change in this patch was SVI-specific. But the logic in update_subnet_precommit() is conditional on whether the network is normal, external, or SVI, and your patch changes that logic a bit. I noticed that _do_test_port_lifecycle() is currently called for normal and external networks, but not for SVI networks. So your current patch is testing the host_routes update for normal and external networks in that function, and for normal and SVI networks in this function. Unless most of what is currently tested in _do_test_port_lifecycle() really does not apply to SVI networks, I think it would make more sense to use _do_test_port_lifecycle() test to test the host_routes update for all three types of networks.

SVI actually doesn't apply to the external networks.....But I checked the code and looks like we don't really prevent that from happening which should be fixed in a separate patch. So based on that, I think the current patch is good enough to cover all the possible combinations, i.e., internal-regular-network, internal-SVI-network & external-regular-network. If your ok with this then I will work on a separate patch to prevent the external network to be created with SVI flag.

So this is live migration instead of evacuate? The novaclient command host-evacuate-live is already really confusingly named, we shouldn't continue that in OSC, see this really nice blog post from dansmith:

http://www.danplanet.com/blog/2016/03/03/evacuate-in-nova-one-command-to-confuse-us-all/

I would not call this command evacuate in any way, since evacuate is rebuilding instances off of a down (dead) host.

A better name for this would be something "openstack hypervisor migrate --all-servers" or something? Something to note that it's a batch operation rather than per-server which is what "openstack server migrate --live" does.

Yeah nova has a (very stupidly named) operation called "evacuate" and calling this by that name will further confuse the already super confusing issue.

Migrate also has a specific meaning, which is not live. What if we go for something generic that can handle these cases with flags, but not be encumbered by baggage? A proposal:

 openstack hypervisor vacate            # Cold migration
 openstack hypervisor vacate --live     # Live migration
 openstack hypervisor vacate --rebuild  # Rebuild (nova evacuate)

This needs a big fat warning that forcing a destination host during live migration can cause all sorts of problems with resource tracking, like in the compute API reference:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#live-migrate-server-os-migratelive-action

Please follow our convention for mutex options like this of using two boolean destination vars.  Since this is essentially a copy of 'servicer migrate' look there for the correct pattern

https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/contributor/command-options.html#boolean-options

This code is actually just a verbatim copy from the option parsing in the "server migrate" you mention, but I guess I can adapt it to this new style, and probably submit a patch to update "server migrate" to this new style aswell?
Ugh, I didn't look at the options in server migrate, so they are.  Fix these, I'll go back and fix that separately.  This BTW is why I want the same pattern.  In some cases, it actually does matter.

What happens if --target is not specified?

server migrate --live requires the destination name, we should be consistent.

Hm, ok, so server migrate isn't quite right either then, correct?  Let's get this one the way we want and we can use (or follow-up) 460059 to handle server migrate.  I had some questions there I'm not sure if are answered yet, will loop back and check this afternoon.

In my quick reading, --host seems like a better option name than --target since it is a hostname being supplied.  I think then --live is pretty clear.

If "--target" is not specified, the scheduler just picks a different hypervisor. (https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#live-migrate-server-os-migratelive-action)

We might want to rename this to "--host" for consistency, since that's what the API calls this option.

I could also change "--target" to "--live <target>" and "--live" to "--live-auto" as a previous patch for "server migrate --live-auto" command. (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/460059) It's a bit messy, but would make it consistent if that patch is applied.

Or the that patch could be changed to "--live" and with the optional "--target", since live-migration doesn't actually require a target according to server.migrate() call. Which will break existing behavior, but for the better.

kolla/common/config.py.message: Just wondering, any reason not to do this in the template override file as <variable>_replacements?

This would be external to a template override file. So technically you could reuse an existing template override file and then swap out all the packages.  So in the tripleo-case, we have various package names in our template override file.  So if we use this we could have the existing configuration and swap out the packages globally. This eliminates the need to key off of OS/Version.  So this was handy when testing python2-* to python3-* names w/o having to change any of the existing Dockerfiles or templates

Thanks for the explanation. It is a lot cleaner now. I think the key to me was that there are two copies of the instance record and we are setting the dest host instance record here, even _before_ the dest host instance is the one that actively seen by the user.

The analog to resize_instance is prep_snapshot_based_resize_at_source, and this method is analogous to _finish_resize. The big difference is with cross-cell migration these two methods are running against different copies of the instance in different databases, so setting the instance host/node in prep_snapshot_based_resize_at_source would only change the copy on the instance in the source cell DB and affect the ResourceTracker on the source host, but we want to make sure the dest host ResourceTracker is going to be tracking this instance as running on it, which we wouldn't get if we didn't set this here, or before we get here in conductor, e.g. sometime between PrepResizeAtSourceTask and FinishResizeAtDestTask. I mentioned something like that in prep_snapshot_based_resize_at_source too:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/634832/44/nova/compute/manager.py@4763

As far as continuing to keep a placeholder claim on the old_flavor on the source host, the RT on the source host should do that based on the migration record in the source cell database until the user confirms/reverts the migration:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/872a823d9a02f31e266882bfb499673c51fb4075/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L759

I'm not sure if it matters from a dest host/RT/cell DB perspective if we update the instance host/node values here after we've applied the migration context or if we should do it before in conductor (after PrepResizeAtSourceTask but before FinishResizeAtDestTask).

Note also that with same-cell resize it's a bit weird that we update the instance host/node to the dest compute before we even successfully finish on the dest compute, i.e. that finish_migration is successful. In a same-cell resize, if _finish_resize fails for some reason, the instance is marked as being on the dest host so if you reboot or rebuild it that's where it's going to go. With cross-cell resize things are a bit different in that we still have the instance on the source host in the source cell DB so if we fail in this step in the target cell / dest host, conductor won't update the instance mapping to point at the target cell and it will rollback the target cell copy of the instance, so you're left with the instance on the source cell/host and you can reboot it from there as needed to recover.

As an aside, could we have added stubs for all the new methods you're adding in this series and simply bumped this once? I guess not, since that'd mean 5.1 on one machine (without the patch that adds the implmentation) != 5.1 on another (with the patch), but worth asking

Firstly, there is a known (discovered by performance integration testing, so not specifics for components, sorry...) limitation of max 300 nodes deployable by TripleO, meaning e2e.

As for Ironic, that is first of all IPv6 provisioning highly wanted for Edge DCN. I'd be grateful if you contributed more specifics here. Something that comes to my mind is securing untrusted hardware in Edge environments, events based, real-time. E.g. when its GPS loc changes (shipped via telemetry coming from an edge site), we might want instantly mark the node untrusted and power it off/erase/burn-in-flames. That is events based and not doable for today in TripleO (and Ironic?). I hope you got the idea, so you inputs here are highly welcome!

> As for Ironic, that is first of all IPv6 provisioning highly wanted for Edge DCN

Metal3 hasn't solved it yet (I think IPv6 support is relatively fresh in k8s). The problem with IPv6 is that it requires cooperation of a lot of components. E.g. it requires UEFI (not legacy boot), support for Neutron and dnsmasq, etc. You can ping Dan Sneddon or Derek Higgins for details.

> securing untrusted hardware in Edge environments

Getting rid of DHCP and PXE is the first one. PXE can be replaced with virtual media, but that requires switching to Redfish and broader vendor support. DHCP is.. tricky. For IPv6 we can use SLAAC. Otherwise we are thinking of providing IP information via virtual media - this requires coding.

> E.g. when its GPS loc changes (shipped via telemetry coming from an edge site), we might want instantly mark the node untrusted and power it off/erase/burn-in-flames. 

This cannot be done without support from hardware vendors for that. Secure boot and trusted boot can be done. Secure boot is supported in Ironic to an extent already, but needs, again, broader vendor support.

Note that nothing of this is Metal3-specific.

specs/pike/fetch-hostkey-from-port.rst.message: Even if they were, wouldn't key-based authentication put their mind at ease, as it would obviously fail? Or are you proposing this countermeasure just for password-based authentication?

I am not sure I follow you. Once an encrypted channel is established with the MITM, the client will attempt to authenticate with the server. Unless the MITM managed to get hold of the public (and private) keys of the client, the authentication fails and the attack won't be perpetrated. My point being (and assumed I understand enough of how the protocol works), a MITM attack could only really be successful in case password-based authentication is used.

So, what's the point of this complexity when it could be easily mitigated by being a bit extra security conscious (i.e. using key-based authentication)? I am surely missing something, but I'd like to see that elaborated here because it is not 100% clear to me.

But it wouldn't obviously fail. The first time you ssh to a host using key based auth, you have to validate the host key given by the server. If you got MITM'd and accepted the hostkey for a rogue server, that rogue server appropriately masquerade and you'd have no clue. Once you have a trust chain established with the host key, then an MITM attach _would_ fail because the host key verification handshake would fail.

The existing method some people use for this (which doens't work on all clouds, and is also a bit gross) is to have cloud-init print the host key to the server's console log, and then use nova's console log API call to fetch the console log and parse the key from the log stream. It's non-ideal because a) some clouds don't allow console log streaming b) it assumes cloud-init in the image c) you have to fetch the entire boot log before you can do anything. So what _most_ people do is just blindly accept the first hostkey presented for any resource created in the cloud.
fundamentally?

How do you envision this would behave with a security group rule that allows traffic only from certain IP addresses? Will this be expected to bypass security groups entirely and always poke at TCP ports even if the instance is fully locked down?

I think it's likely better to obey security groups. If a user locks down their VM like that and then asks neutron to ping it for a hostkey, I think we should return 408 - or maybe a 403 if we can reliably detect the difference between "network connection timeout" and "network connection refused".

In fact, maybe 403 should just be added as a "the port is active but does not respond to this type of request but didn't timeout"

Sorry if I am being thick, but I am still unclear why you claim that this is a signification improvement in general terms. The extra security conscious users should adopt host-based authentication to thwart any MITM attack. This extra security layer feels like shooting a fly with a cannon, when a simple fly swatter would do.

I am not arguing against the addition of this extension; I am simply trying to understand the rationale better because otherwise it seems like only a marginal improvement rather a significant one, as claimed here.

From the problem description I assume the threat model is something like the following:

An attacker sits somewhere on the network between the victim client and the cloud itself. The attacker has no access to or control of the cloud, but can intercept and block network traffic to the extent that they can successfully MITM connections between the victim client and the cloud, including SSH connections.

In this scenario, even if a client uses SSH key-based authentication, at the first connection attempt to the server the rogue server in the middle can return its key instead of the real server's key and the victim client cannot tell this is happening.  If the client then assumes they have a secure connection to the real server and uploads a bunch of sensitive data, then the attacker has what they want, with no need to actually get into the real server in the cloud which is successfully protected by key-based SSH.


Given such a threat model and attack scenario I think the proposed solution is a good one as long as the security groups are obeyed.  How likely is this threat model to be realized in the real world? Sadly, we have seen much evidence over the last few years of highly specialized and powerful attack tools leaking out, so such an attack is plausible today.  The security and peace of mind provided by this is worth the complexity.  It is a hole in what we have today, and this is a good way to plug that hole.

Yes - that is exactly correct.

Also - by making it an opt-in call, we shouldn't increase the overhead for users who don't care, but will empower the users who do care. At least, I hope that's what we do :)
Makes sense. I thought the attack target was the cloud server all along, when in reality this can be far more damaging to the client. Thanks for providing further insight Bryan!

We need to push for strongly typed errors everywhere.  I understand we are currently consuming the Nordix redfish library and this may be more feedback on that then this code but given this is a consumer, I am putting it here.  However, anyone who leverages a third-party package should be responsible for turning its string-based error messages to strongly typed errors for consumers to switch on. I really want to see every pkg/* implement: 
  - an errors.go file containing all strongly typed errors for that pkg.
  - strongly typed error types for each type of error, and only return those to external package consumers.

pkg/remote/remote_direct.go.message: Would it make sense to replace this with a call to RemoteDirectError or RedfishError?

I don't know if this is exactly weighing in on the question but I personally don't think we want to get in the business of re-wrapping errors everywhere.  I think the basic mantra should be: try to create strongly typed errors for certain conditions that may be useful for callers to know.  For instance, to me strongly typed errors would be achieving something like returning RemoteDirectValidationError (input data is bad), RemoteDirectUnreachableError (you could retry), so on.  These are the types of strongly typed errors which I think give value here beyond one global RemoteDirectError / RedfishError.  I suppose these are a good place to start though.   Even when we have this though, I think all callers casing on err.(type) will have to be able to account for "unknown" errors anyways so there is no sense in re-wrapping every err encountered.

err is already ReadfishError. This was my question in meeting about error propagation. Do we need to wrap inner errors everywhere? Simple text wrapping will lose its type. Widely used way is to record the stack in err where error was originated and not wrap it in each layer. Do you want me to do something like that? If yes, then there are several of those small error libraries which do this thing. Can we use one of those? In this way you can also wrap the errors like from 3rd party libs to local error types. And later at top level unwind the err stack to see the source of error.

manila/share/drivers/nexenta/ns5/nexenta.message: I can't see this driver handling share servers yet..
This driver doesn't support creating/managing share servers, so this should just be False.

This value will be wrong if the manila-share service is deployed in an active-active fashion. Can you instead enumerate the shares and sizes in the periodic thread (_get_share_stats()) and sum them up dynamically?

This should have been "id". However, looking at the current state of this driver, it always used share['name'], which resolves to "share-"+share['share_id'] instead of share['id']. 

 

Using the "share_id" is not recommended, because it pertains to a logical share in the manila database that can be back-ended by many physical shares in the storage.

 

During normal operation, a logical manila share only has one physical share. However, with share replication and share migration, the same logical manila share will have more than one physical shares that it refers to. This driver doesn't currently implement share replication, but may, in the future; and this may turn out to be an issue.

same comment as above. The recommended naming on the backend is to use snapshot['id'] -> This id parameter is exclusive to each snapshot, even when the share that it belongs to has replicas, or is part of a share group or is being migrated across storage backends.

The update_access call into the driver can present a batch of access rules - if you raise an exception in this code path, it will set all access rules within that batch in an "error" state. These "error" rules are not presented to the driver again, and the only recourse is that the user that added these rules must remove all of them and re-add the rules. 

This is undesirable...  

Please handle errors for individual access rules, and return the specific rule as being invalid to your driver... See: https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/d877b61c5e37ff012341194b8349af6f38155e5d/manila/share/driver.py#L750

Same comment here; although - this check (that the IP address or network subnet used as the client) is performed in the API, you can drop it. See: https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/6d970b7375689eb73fc6a26ceb1c4d6e5553fa70/manila/api/common.py#L368

Why not retrieve this from the backend periodically, through the method on line 137.

If multiple instances of the manila-share process are deployed in an active-active manner, each instance of your driver will report its own provisioned capacity based on the shares it was responsible to create.

oh.. ty for letting me know; if you want to do the provisioned capacity gb calculation in the driver safely, you can:

- Isolate a method to handle updates to provisioned capacity Gb, and write this data into your driver's private data - it's a dedicated database table for all instances of your driver [1] Example instantiation in the ZFSOnLinux driver is here [2]
- Ensure concurrency control on that driver method with the help of a distributed tooz lock [2]


[1] https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/cd078020f6140fb401ea59837728d58c5f9bcb34/manila/share/drivers_private_data.py#L42
[2] https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/d7c01efb444b7bf02c1729be3554abebaee473a3/manila/share/drivers/zfsonlinux/driver.py#L180
[3] https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/97cfb648c4ec24f996d79e95e11484aa6ad586c7/manila/coordination.py#L152

Unfortunately at this point the API call I was initially going to use in _get_provisioned_capacity method is not returning the value we are looking for. 
So the only way to poll the backed for exact provisioned capacity would have to iterate through all the shares on it and send an API request for each, meaning at least N+1 calls for N shares. This does not seem like a good idea for any production setup with at least 100 shares or more.

At this point I see only two possibilities: either get the initial provisioned capacity from the manila DB and calculate new ones as the driver is doing right now or just report 0. 

Would really like to get your input on this.
ENOENT? Actually your delete method already filters ENOENT, it is expected to receive a EEXIST from a delete cmd?

In a ZFS system deleting a filesystem that has children (i.e. snapshots) will return a EEXIST error saying that it has children. In this case we try to delete with snapshots, but those snapshots may also have children (read clones) and so on. That is why in this case we iterate over all snapshots and find the one with the largest creationTxg (which means it was created the latest) and promote it.

nova/compute/api.py.message: This is wrong, swap_volume is on an existing instance.

This is where we process the user-requested server AZ (or default to CONF.default_schedule_zone).

This happens long before we get to _provision_instances.
don't see where we checked and judged that user didn't request an AZ?

It's confusing and the flow is very tightly coupled, but when the server create request is being processed, we call the parse_availability_zone() method (in this class) which will parse the AZ that the user specified and if one was not specified by the user, we default to CONF.default_schedule_zone (which defaults to None). So by the time we get to _validate_bdm and it eventually calls nova.volume.cinder.API.check_availability_zone, the instance.availability_zone should be set from the request (or the default_schedule_zone) and we can compare it to the requested volume's AZ.

I thought about trying to decouple all of this so we don't need the volume_az coming back from way down in check_availability_zone, but it would be a bit inefficient since we'd have to add a check in here before eventually getting to _validate_bdm, something like:

1. if instance.availability_zone is None
2. if not CONF.cinder.cross_az_attach
3. find the root bdm (if there is one for boot from volume)
4. if the root bdm is a volume, get the volume
5. compare the instance.availability_zone to the volume's AZ
6. then do the same logic as I've added to check_availability_zone() in this patch, but instead of returning volume_az back up the stack, just set it on the instance.availability_zone and requestspec here. We'll still eventually end up getting the volume again and comparing the AZ even though we would have already done that - which is inefficient.

Anyway, what I have here isn't pretty but it fixes the issue (which has been a problem ever since cross_az_attach was added a long long time ago).

> oh, got it we are comparing instance.az with volume az, I thought
 > req_spec.az is the instance.az.

The RequestSpec.availability_zone is meant to be what the user requested during server create and what will go to the scheduler for the AvailabilityZoneFilter. Once the scheduler picks a host based on the requested AZ, conductor will lookup the AZ for the host and set that on instance.availability_zone:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/eb4f65a7951e921b1cd8d05713e144e72f2f254f/nova/conductor/manager.py#L1254
oh, got it we are comparing instance.az with volume az, I thought req_spec.az is the instance.az.
This is where the requested (or configured default) AZ gets stored on the request spec.
Thanks.
Is this the only place where we save the AZ to the request spec? I grepped for others and didn't find any.
No, see above.
Note to self: this is called with this default in attach_volume.

Per my comment in cinder.py, I think the logic for what to do should be here (or this should be a call to a helper function nearby.

 if not instance_az:
     req_spec.az = volume_az
 elif instance_az != volume_az and not CONF.cross_az_attach:
     # explode

Now, perhaps the elif case needs to remain buried in the cinder stuff so that cleanup happens properly? If so, that's fine, but the very nova-specific bit of choosing to put the volume az in the reqspec should happen out here and not deep in the volume api code, IMHO.

As far as your comment on PS4 about decoupling the attach bit from the determination fo the volume AZ, I'm not as concerned about that. It's all crazy tightly coupled as it is. I think not adding more (i.e. my complaint in that file) is good, but this fix is backportable as it is, and further refactoring would make that less good.

> Per my comment in cinder.py, I think the logic for what to do
 > should be here (or this should be a call to a helper function
 > nearby.
 > 
 > if not instance_az:
 > req_spec.az = volume_az
 > elif instance_az != volume_az and not CONF.cross_az_attach:
 > # explode

The tricky thing with that is we don't want to set req_spec.az = volume_az if the volume_az is 'nova' because of default az in config, because that's like the user requesting the az to be 'nova' on the server which means it can't migrate between AZs later, which is the warning we have in the docs:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/availability-zones.html

And this:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/availability-zones.html#implications-for-moving-servers

That's why the cinder.py code is checking CONF.default_availability_zone which defaults to 'nova'.

Note that CONF.default_schedule_zone defaults to None but if it's set then it will be set in instance_az in the logic above before we even get here.

> the very nova-specific bit of choosing to put the volume az in the reqspec should happen out here and not deep in the volume api code

It is happening here. I haven't read the other comment yet though, but maybe you mean the calculation of whether or not we need the volume AZ here way down there is what you're talking about, which I'd agree is the gross part.

Why only is_root? If I create an instance with multiple volumes, they better all be in the same az. Also, even if I create an ephemeral instance with a data volume (i.e. not root), it needs to be in the same AZ.
You're right, I'm not sure why I was restricting to the root BDM since cross_az_attach applies to all volumes attached to the server.
Presumably we only want to do this once, and on the second and later cases, make sure that they're equivalent right?
You mean once volume_az is set from at least one volume, if we encounter another in the list of bdms with a different AZ then we blow up? Yeah I agree.

I should probably remove this. Even if the API did allow a list of IDs it depends on the semantics, i.e. if it's like an IN filter then it probably wouldn't 404 if any are missing and that's not the behavior we want here.
Done

Agree that we should be able to ignore, but why not just always return the volume AZ if instance_az is None? The only thing I can think of is something related to pinning the instance in the volume's AZ or something (can't remember if it's sticky now anymore). Just seems like one less branch if we just explicitly take the volume's AZ.
Done
If I respin I'll add a comment about this as well since it's confusing.

The case to worry about is the default one, where the default AZ is 'nova' in both nova and cinder:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#DEFAULT.default_availability_zone

https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/6074b9bfcb9278790833e8b3a36803e106d79c67/cinder/common/config.py#L94

And that is not good if we pin the instance to the 'nova' AZ per the warning here:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/availability-zones.html

Specifically:

"""
Consequently, it is highly recommended for users to never ever ask for booting an instance by specifying an explicit AZ named nova and for operators to never set the AZ metadata for an aggregate to nova. This can result is some problems due to the fact that the instance AZ information is explicitly attached to nova which could break further move operations when either the host is moved to another aggregate or when the user would like to migrate the instance.
"""

So that's my reasoning here anyway.
If it makes things easier I could split this out into a separate change before _validate_vol_az_for_create is added.
This being False is tested by test_validate_bdm_media_service_valid.
and we should be able to use for unshelve also https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/api.py#L3762

if there no volumes being attached, this will be failed?
Yeah I think you're right. Unit tests likely missed this since they probably mock this method out and functional tests probably missed it since they use volumes when cross_az_attach=False.
Fixed with a new functional test "test_cross_az_attach_false_no_volumes" which is easier and more trustworthy than stubbing everything out through unit tests.

nova/volume/cinder.py.message: Seems like this should be CONF.default_schedule_zone but that defaults to None so it wouldn't help us here when the volume has a default AZ of "nova". But maybe should use CONF.default_schedule_zone or CONF.default_availability_zone in case CONF.default_schedule_zone is set?

We should probably use CONF.default_schedule_zone.

Alternatively, if cross_az_attach=False and the user didn't explicitly request an AZ for the instance, we need the instance to be in the same AZ as the volume, but if the volume is in the default AZ (nova), do we just bypass this check - we could set the RequestSpec.availability_zone = volume.availability_zone, but we don't want to do that if the volume AZ is the default (nova) because we don't want users requesting 'nova' for the AZ:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/aggregates.html#availability-zones-azs

So maybe we should do something like this:

if instance_az is None and default_az:
    # Use default_schedule_zone if set (defaults to None).
    if CONF.default_schedule_zone:
        instance_az = CONF.default_schedule_zone
        if instance_az != volume['availability_zone']:
            msg = _("Instance %(instance)s and volume %(vol)s are not in "
                    "the same availability_zone. Instance is in "
                    "%(ins_zone)s. Volume is in %(vol_zone)s") % {
                        "instance": instance.uuid,
                         "vol": volume['id'],
                         'ins_zone': instance_az,
                         'vol_zone': volume['availability_zone']}
            raise exception.InvalidVolume(reason=msg)
    else:
        # Check if the volume AZ is the same as our default
        # AZ for compute hosts (nova) and if so, assume we are
        # OK because the user didn't request an AZ and will
        # get the same default. If the volume AZ is not the
        # same as our default, use the volume AZ and put it
        # into the request spec so the instance is scheduled
        # to the same zone as the volume.
        volume_az = volume['availability_zone']
        if volume_az != CONF.default_availability_zone:
            return volume_az  # indication to set in request spec
        # the volume az is the same as the default nova az
        # so we'll be OK and just return
        return

This is redundant because instance.availability_zone will be set in parse_availability_zone if the user didn't request an AZ, and if CONF.default_schedule_zone is not None, then "if instance_az is None" on L521 will be False.

Just to be clear, "Should only be True before the instance is scheduled to a host" because after the instance is scheduled to a host, the request spec or instance will be updated with an AZ? In which case this method should not be called with default_az=True?

Once the instance is scheduled to a host, conductor updates the instance.availability_zone to the AZ that the selected host is in, yes:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/20bc0136d0665bafdcd379f19389a0a5ea7bf310/nova/conductor/manager.py#L1287

So, before this change, this method returns None if cross_az_attach=False and the instance AZ matches the volume AZ. So that part stays the same. Before this change, the method raises if the instance AZ does not match the volume AZ, if cross_az_attach=False.

What's new is this method will return the volume AZ if the instance has no requested AZ and the volume AZ does not match the default AZ.

This feels weird and like it's adding a ternary mode of behavior to this method and adding confusion to how this method works. The code comments help, but still. I don't have a better idea, though.

Yeah it's super tightly coupled and nasty. I have an alternative idea to how this can be handled in an earlier patch set comment:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/469675/4/nova/compute/api.py@918

I just haven't tried writing that alternative yet.
Ah, I see. I thought about similar alternatives and the complexity and inefficiency that would have to happen if we went a different route.

Okay, this is super confusing to me. I think what default_az=True really just means "return the cinder az, if we should be forcing the instance to the same nova az" right?

IMHO, that's burying some very nova-specific logic deep in the volume api code. Really it seems like we should just always return the volume az and then do our "what should we do with the cinder az" logic above.

When reading all the code that has "attach" or "reserve" in the name, and has a parameter of default_az=True, I had assumed that meant "create the volume in the default cinder az". Until I came here to find out what the end result was, I had a very different idea.

> IMHO, that's burying some very nova-specific logic deep in the volume api code.

Well this is all nova-specific logic since cross_az_attach is a nova-only configuration (even though cinder has an option to workaround it [allow_allow_availability_zone_fallback]) but yeah I get what you're saying. The default_az parameter was needed to distinguish between when the API calls this before scheduling the instance to host (and AZ) and when nova-compute calls this to check a volume it created. But I think I get your point.

> Really it seems like we should just always return the volume az and then do our "what should we do with the cinder az" logic above.

Yeah that makes sense, but I'd have to think about refactoring this, since if this method doesn't raise InvalidVolume like it did, then the compute service usage of it changes.

Maybe the API shouldn't even be calling this method and the API can have a specific check for cross_az_attach and compute can have a specific check for cross_az_attach and that would help avoid the confusion over trying to make this single method do double duty (I would probably just move this method to nova.virt.block_device in that case).

If we bump up the delays significantly, then we would hold up periodic tasks for nothing.

Even if all these timings fail miserably in some slow environment, nothing bad would really happen I think.

Does it make sense? What do you think would be a better approach?

def get_session(conf, requests_session=None, group=None, timeout=None):

    """Get a ceilometer service credentials auth session."""
    group = group or DEFAULT_GROUP
    auth_plugin = ka_loading.load_auth_from_conf_options(conf, group)
    kwargs = {'auth': auth_plugin, 'session': requests_session}
    if timeout is not None:
        kwargs['timeout'] = timeout
    session = ka_loading.load_session_from_conf_options(conf, group, **kwargs)
    return session
